questions.text: A 44-year-old man came to ophthalmology OPD with C/O vision loss for the past few weeks. Fundus examination revealed Bull’s eye maculopathy. On history taking, the patient said that he had been taking some medication for the past three years. Which drug on chronic use would have caused this fundus change?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chloroquine Prolonged use of high doses of Chloroquine may cause vision loss due to retinal damage. Fundus examination shows Bull’s eye maculopathy. Corneal deposits may also occur & affect vision but are reversible on discontinuation, unlike irreversible retinal

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Ethambutol causes loss of visual acuity/color vision and field defects due to retrobulbar neuritis. Patients should be instructed to stop the drug at the first indication of visual impairment. Option: C . Sulfasalazine causes crystalluria & hepatitis. Haemolysis can occur in G-6-PD deficient individuals. Kernicterus may be precipitated, especially in the premature newborn. Option: D . Amphotericin B in the long term causes nephrotoxicity, anaemia due to bone marrow depression & CNS toxicity on intrathecal injection.

questions.text: A 10-week pregnant woman came to the OPD with C/O intermittent fever, chills & increased sweating. The laboratory investigations showed that she was suffering from Plasmodium vivax malaria. The drug of choice for this patient is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chloroquine Vivax malaria during pregnancy can be treated with chloroquine as in non-pregnant, but radical cure with primaquine should be postponed till after delivery , as it is implicated in hemolysis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy since it may cause G6PD deficiency in the fetus. Option: C. Paracetamol may decrease symptoms of malaria for a brief period, but it cannot give a cure Option: D. Artemether should be avoided in the first trimester of pregnancy & during breastfeeding. It can be used after the completion of the first trimester in cases of falciparum malaria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female diagnosed with malaria was given a drug for the treatment of malaria. After a few days, she came to the casualty with C/O profuse sweating, giddiness & palpitations. Her blood glucose level was 48 mg/dL. Which anti-malarial drug would have caused this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Quinine The patient came to the casualty with C/O profuse sweating, giddiness & palpitations. Her blood glucose level was 48 mg/dl. This shows that she has hypoglycemia. That is why quinine infusion should be given in D5. Quinine will cause delirium, fever, tachypnoea, respiratory depression, pulmonary edema, hypoglycemia, marked weakness & prostration.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Chloroquine on prolonged use may cause vision loss due to retinal damage. Corneal deposits, loss of hearing, rashes, photoallergy, mental disturbances, myopathy & greying of hair can occur on long-term use. Option: C. Primaquine causes dose-related hemolysis, especially in G6PD deficient individuals, methemoglobinemia, tachypnoea & cyanosis. Option: D. Pyrimethamine is relatively safe. The only side effects are occasional nausea & rashes. Megaloblastic anemia & granulocytopenia may occur with higher doses.

questions.text: A 10-week pregnant woman came to the OPD with C/O intermittent fever, chills & increased sweating. The laboratory investigations showed that she was suffering from Plasmodium falciparum malaria. The drug of choice for this patient is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Quinine Falciparum malaria during pregnancy Quinine 600 mg TDS × 7 days + clindamycin 300 mg TDS/QID (20 mg/kg/day) for 7 days can be used during all trimesters & is a safer option during 1st trimester.

Highyeild:

Quinine • Alkaloid from cinchona bark • Used for muscle cramps, abortion, suicide - Quinidine is an isomer of quinine • Cinchonism - Tinnitus, vertigo - Headache, nausea, vomiting Diarrhea - Hot, flushed skin, sweating - Delirium, ventricular tachycardia • Optic atrophy (ganglion cell damage), congenital blindness in unsuccessful abortions

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Chloroquine is indicated for vivax malaria during pregnancy. Option: B. Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy since it may cause G6PD deficiency in the fetus. Option: D . Artemether should be avoided in the first trimester of pregnancy & during breastfeeding. It can be used after the completion of the first trimester in cases of falciparum malaria.

Extraedge:

Quinidine Bind to sodium channels and prevent sodium influx, and so slower the rapid depolarization. Slows repolarization & lengthens AP duration→ due to K+ channel blockade with reduction of repolarizing outward current → reduce maximum reentry frequency → slows tachycardia Inhibit arrhythmias, which caused by increased automoticity, and also prevent reentry arrhythmias by producing bidirectional block.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male came with C/O intermittent fever, chills & abdominal pain. Peripheral blood smear showed the presence of malarial parasites. The drug of choice for exo erythrocytic stage of this parasite is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primaquine Primaquine is the drug of choice for the exo erythrocytic stage of the malarial parasite.

Highyeild:

STAGE DRUGS Pre erythrocytic Primaquine, Proguanil, Atovaquone, pyremethamine Exo erythrocytic Primaquine, Tafenoquine Erythrocytic Doxycycline, Chloroquine, Mefloquine Gametocytic Primaquine, Artemisinin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Chloroquine & Option D. Mefloquine acts against the erythrocytic stage of the malarial parasite. Option: B. Proguanil acts against the pre-erythrocytic stage of the malarial parasite.

Extraedge:

Primaquine Adverse effects Abdnominal pain, gastrointestinal upset, weakness or uneasiness chest Leucopenia (high dose) Hemolysis Methaemoglobinaemia Tachypnoea Cyanosis

questions.text: An Englishman wants to visit Chloroquine & Mefloquine-resistant malaria region. The drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Doxycycline

Highyeild:

Chemoprophylaxis of malaria should be limited to short-term (< 6 weeks) use in special risk groups, such as travelers to northeastern malaria endemic states (army units, labour forces). Mefloquine is a prophylactic with proven efficacy but should not be used in subjects with a history of neuropsychiatric illness, convulsions/ heart disease & for mefloquine-resistant falciparum areas (Myanmar, Thailand, Cambodia). Doxycycline 100 mg daily starting the day before travel & taken till 4 weeks after return from an endemic area for CQ-resistant falciparum is suitable for short-term (maximum 6 weeks) visitors. It is contraindicated in pregnant women & children < 8 yr.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Hydroxychloroquine is not used in the chemoprophylaxis of malaria & also cannot be used in CQ-resistant cases. Option: C. Quinine & Option D . Primaquine are not used as chemoprophylaxis for malaria. Option: D. Primaquine is a medication used to treat and prevent malaria and to treat Pneumocystis pneumonia. Specifically, it is used for malaria due to Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale and other medications and for prevention, if other options cannot be used.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female diagnosed with malaria has been treated with an anti-malarial drug. The doctor advises the patient to take this drug with fatty food or milk. Which of the following drug would have been prescribed to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lumefantrine Lumefantrine must be administered with fatty food/ milk, which markedly enhances its absorption & ensures adequate blood levels. Failure to take it with fat-rich food limits absorption & may result in recrudescence.

Highyeild:

Mechanism of action The precise antimalarial action of lumefantrine and artemether is unknown, although both appear to act on the parasite's organelles, where they are thought to interfere with the conversion of haem to nontoxic compounds. Artemether contains an endoperoxide bridge, which interacts with haem iron to generate reactive metabolites. Lumefantrine is thought to interfere with haem polymerisation, a critical detoxifying pathway for the malaria parasite. - Both artemether and lumefantrine have a secondary action, inhibiting nucleic acid and protein synthesis within the parasite.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Chloroquine , Option C. Mefloquine & Option D. Amodiaquine have excellent oral absorption, and these drugs don’t need food to enhance their absorption. Option: C. Mefloquine is a medication used to prevent or treat malaria. When used for prevention, it typically starts before potential exposure and continues for several weeks after potential exposure. It can be used to treat mild or moderate malaria. Option: D. Amodiaquine is a medication used to treat malaria, including Plasmodium falciparum malaria, when uncomplicated. It is recommended to be given with artesunate to reduce the risk of resistance due to the risk of rare but serious side effects.

Extraedge:

Artemether-lumefantrine Drug Mechanism of action Uses Adverse Effects Artemether- lumefantrine (COARTEM) tablet 20mg/120mg Half-Life: artemether 2 hr: lumefantrine 3-6 days Both artemether and lumentantrine inhibit nucleic acid and protein synthesis Metabolism via lumefantrine:CYP2D6 artemether: CYP3A4 Treatment of acute attack of malaria Cerebral malaria Abdominal pain Anorexia Arthralgia Chills Dizziness Fatigue Headache Myalgia

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came to the casualty with signs of ataxia, confusion, irritability & hallucinations. On history taking, the doctor learned that he is a known case of cerebral malaria and has been under medication for 3 months. Which of the following drug would have caused this condition in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mefloquine

Highyeild:

The above signs show that the patient is having a a neuropsychiatric reaction. Mefloquine causes neuropsychiatric reactions (disturbed sense of balance, ataxia, errors in operating machinery, strange dreams, anxiety, hallucinations, rarely convulsions), sinus bradycardia & Q-T prolongation. These are dose-related & subside over 1–3 weeks on discontinuation. Patients recovering from cerebral malaria are more prone to develop convulsions. MQ is contraindicated in patients with anxiety, depression, psychosis & in those with cardiac conduction defects.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Quinine will cause delirium, fever, tachypnoea followed by respiratory depression, pulmonary edema, hypoglycaemia, marked weakness & prostration. Option: C. Chloroquine on prolonged use may cause loss of vision due to retinal damage. Corneal deposits, loss of hearing, rashes, photoallergy, mental disturbances, myopathy & greying of hair can occur on long-term use. Option: D. Artesunate produces mild adverse effects like nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, itching, drug fever, delayed haemolysis & other hypersensitivity reactions. Headache, tinnitus, dizziness, bleeding, dark urine, transient reticulopenia & leucopenia are rare & subside when the patient improves/ the drug is stopped.

Extraedge:

Mefloquine Adverse effects MQ is bitter in taste At high doses: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, bradycardia Ataxia, hallucinations, depression MQ is safe in pregnancy Rare events of toxicity are seen Contraindications In patients with anxiety, depression, psychosis, and in cardiac conduction defects

questions.text: A 35-year-old male diagnosed with malaria 3 days back has been under chloroquine therapy for the past 3 days. Now the doctor prescribes him the drug Primaquine for the radical cure. Which other drug can be used for the radical cure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tafenoquine Tafenoquine is similar to Primaquine, and it has been recently approved for the radical cure of malaria. It has a long plasma t½ of 14–19 days (t½ of primaquine is 6–8 hours). Thus, a single dose is enough for the radical cure, whereas primaquine has to be given for 14 days.

Highyeild:

Mechanism of action Tafenoquine interferes with mitochondrial function leading to the apoptotic-like death of the organism ↓ Tafenoquine induced mitochondrial dysfunction through the inhibition of cytochrome c reductase (respiratory complex III) ↓ Decrease in the oxygen consumption rate and depolarization of mitochondrial membrane potential. ↓ Reactive oxygen species generation, elevation of intracellular calcium levels and concomitant nuclear DNA fragmentation In addition, tafenoquine inhibits haematin polymerization (like chloroquine, but unlike primaquine, which is inactive in this regard) PRIMAQUINE ← TAFENOQUINE

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Mefloquine is an effective drug for multiresistant falciparum malaria & for prophylaxis of malaria among travellers to areas with multidrug resistance. Option: C. Quinine is used in uncomplicated resistant falciparum malaria, complicated & severe malaria, including cerebral malaria, and nocturnal muscle cramps. Option; D. Amodiaquine is used in falciparum malaria, irrespective of CQ-resistance status.

Extraedge:

The proposed indication for tafenoquine is for treatment of the hypnozoite stages of Plasmodium vivax (and also Plasmodium ovale) that are responsible for relapse of these malaria species even when the blood stages are successfully cleared. Currently, this is only achieved by administration of daily primaquine for 14 days. The main advantage of tafenoquine is that it has a long half-life (2-3 weeks) and therefore a single treatment may be sufficient to clear hypnozoites. The shorter regimen has been described as an advantage
